title: 106_s2451
content: FRAUD AND RELATED ACTIVITY IN CONNECTION WITH COMPUTERS. Increase in Criminal Penalties for Computer Crimes under Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, includes amendments to subsections (a)(4) and (c) to increase penalties for causing damage. This involves changes such as increasing the maximum sentence from 5 to 10 years for certain offenses. Additionally, the damage threshold under Section 1030(e)(8) is improved with amendments to increase penalties for computer crimes. The amendment increases penalties for causing damage under Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, by redesignating subparagraphs and inserting a clause for loss or interruption of service to the general public. The amendment increases penalties for causing damage under Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code, by redesignating subparagraphs and inserting a clause for loss or interruption of service to the general public. Additionally, a National Commission on Cybersecurity is established. The National Commission on Cybersecurity is established with 12 members appointed by various leaders. Each member must meet specific qualifications. The National Commission on Cybersecurity consists of 12 members appointed by leaders, with qualifications in law enforcement, technology, or security. The Commission elects a Chairperson and Vice Chairperson, with a majority required for a quorum. Appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members of the Commission are entitled to 1 vote each, vacancies do not affect its powers, and members do not receive additional pay but may be reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission will study computer crimes and make recommendations on improving coordination among federal agencies, creating criminal laws to deter computer crimes, and enhancing international coordination. The initial meeting of the Commission must occur within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission will study computer crimes, improve coordination among federal agencies, create criminal laws to deter computer crimes, enhance international coordination, and submit a final report to the President and Congress within 1 year. The Commission may hold hearings and adopt rules and regulations as necessary for carrying out the Act. Recommendations require a majority vote of Commission members for submission to the President and Congress. The Commission may request information from federal agencies for the purpose of the Act, and agencies must provide information upon request. The Commission can request facilities, services, and personnel from federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties under the Act. Additionally, the Commission is allowed to use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. The Commission can enter into contracts for research and surveys, appoint staff, and set compensation in accordance with appropriation Acts. The Commission can appoint an executive director and additional staff at rates not exceeding the maximum rate for level IV of the Executive Schedule. Expenses of the Commission are authorized up to $500,000, with funds remaining available until expended or 1 year after the Commission's termination. The Commission will terminate at a specified time. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting its final report.
